author: Diederik
message: How about $VIM/vimfiles/plugins ? I've got some plugins in "C:\Program Files\Vim\vimfiles\plugin" and this works perfectly.

author: Aurélien
message: Sure, but this assumes you have write access to "C:\Program Files", so if you are not running Windows with Administrator privileges, you're stuck.

author: Domle
message:
I've newer worked out from "Documents and Settings", - Have an aversion to spaced folder/file-names and. But anyhow. Have a directory named "home" in c root. Within this I have user folders. To get vim running smooth i have added this to the top of gvim.bat:


rem -+- *** CONF *** -+-
SET PATH=c:/tool/git/bin;%PATH%
SET HOME=c:/home/%USERNAME%
SET HOMEPATH=/home/%USERNAME%
SET USERPROFILE=c:/home/%USERNAME%
SET LANG=en_US.UTF-8
SET ALLUSERSPROFILE=c:/home/share
rem -+- *** *** -+-

LANG is to get rid of my locale, - can be set in "Environment Variables" as well and get rid of locale language in several other apps as well. (Like to have it in English)

In my .vimrc file I have:


set backupdir=~/.vim/backup " Backup directory
set runtimepath=~/.vim,$VIMRUNTIME " YESSS! here to
" http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/starting.html#:rviminfo
" http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/options.html#'viminfo'
set viminfo=n~/.viminfo " To force win-vim to use dot viminfo

Works like a charm...

author: Mark Shepherd
message:
Another note: if snipMate is installed into your ~/vimfiles & it's showing it's four files loaded @ :scriptnames, try deleting C:\Program Files\vimfiles\*.*

See http://www.vim.org/scripts/...

Cheers,
-- MarkShepherd
